questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jonah 1:1-17 aloud, focusing on the emotional shift from Jonah's disobedience to the sailors' reaction to the storm.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the LORD' (4 times) shows Jonah's fear of God
Pay attention to the phrase 'flee' (v.3) indicating avoidance of God's call
The emotional tone shifts from Jonah's anger to the sailors' fear (v.10)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jonah) does WHAT (flees to Tarshish), WHERE (from Joppa to sea), and WHY (to avoid God's command to preach to Nineveh).
tips: Include Jonah's initial disobedience (v.3)
Note the storm's cause (v.2-3) and sailors' action (v.10-12)
Describe how Jonah was thrown into the sea (v.11-12)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jonah's response to the storm (v.11), the sailors' immediate action (v.12), or God's control of the storm (v.2).
tips: Jonah's words show he understands the storm is his fault (v.11) - a moment of clarity
The sailors' quick action (v.12) contrasts with Jonah's earlier avoidance
God's active role in the storm (v.2) demonstrates His sovereignty over nature

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jonah trying to communicate to Israel through this passage about God's call?
tips: Jonah's flight shows the danger of disobedience to God's call for repentance
The storm and Jonah's being thrown overboard symbolize God's sovereignty and consequences of refusal
This passage highlights that God's call must be responded to, even when it's costly

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The reason for Jonah's flight, the nature of the storm, or the sailors' lot practice?
tips: Jonah's flight was political - he didn't want to preach to Assyria (a pagan enemy of Israel)
The storm is not natural but a divine punishment (v.2) showing God's wrath
The lot (v.10) was a common practice for divination but here it assigned blame to Jonah

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: When have you tried to run from God's call in your life? What step can you take to stop and trust Him this week?
tips: Consider an area where you're avoiding God's guidance (e.g., sin, anxiety, decisions)
Pray for courage to face God's call instead of fleeing
Ask God to show you where you need to be obedient this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His sovereignty and ask for courage to obey Him in difficult circumstances.
tips: Thank God that He controls your life (like the storm)
Pray for the strength to face God's call when it's costly
Ask God to help you not run from Him but trust Him in the storm

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jonah 2:1-11 aloud, focusing on the emotional intensity of Jonah's prayer and the repetition of his distress.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I' and 'you' to show Jonah's intimate relationship with God
Pay attention to the phrase 'out of the belly of Sheol' (v.3) which conveys deep despair
Listen for the shift in tone from despair (v.1-3) to hope (v.4-10)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who is praying, what God is doing, where this occurs, and why Jonah is praying.
tips: Include Jonah's three days in the fish (v.2)
Note that Jonah is in the belly of the fish (Sheol) and the deep waters
Describe God's response: bringing Jonah up from the pit (v.10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part of Jonah's prayer stood out most? Consider: the call for help (v.1), the drowning imagery (v.3), or the thanksgiving (v.10)?
tips: The phrase 'I called out to the LORD, out of my distress' (v.1) shows Jonah's desperate need
The description of being surrounded by the deep waters ('the deep surrounded me') (v.3) is a powerful image of being trapped
The declaration 'Salvation belongs to the LORD!' (v.10) is a strong affirmation of God's sovereignty

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jonah trying to communicate to Israel through this passage of prayer?
tips: Jonah was a prophet who ran from God (1:1-17), so this prayer shows that even when we run from God, He remains faithful
The prayer emphasizes that God is present in the deepest places (Sheol) and will save those who call on Him
This passage points to the universal nature of God's salvation: not limited to Israel

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging to understand? Consider cultural context, unfamiliar terms, or theological concepts.
tips: 'Sheol' (v.3) is the Hebrew term for the underworld, but in this context, Jonah is in the belly of the fish and also in Sheol (the place of the dead) – this shows the depth of his despair
The phrase 'three days and three nights' (v.2) is a common biblical phrase (also used for Christ's death and resurrection), but Jonah was in the fish for exactly that time
The declaration 'Salvation belongs to the LORD alone' (v.10) is a strong statement that there is no other salvation – this contrasts with Jonah's earlier rebellion (1:1-17)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Jonah's experience of being saved from the deep to your life this week?
tips: When you feel trapped or in a dark place, remember that God is with you and can bring you out
Pray like Jonah: 'I called out to the LORD, out of my distress' (v.1) when you are in a difficult situation
Surrender your situation to God, trusting that He will bring you salvation (v.10)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about Jonah's prayer: Thank God for His salvation and ask for the courage to trust Him in your own darkness.
tips: Thank God that He brings you out of the pit when you feel abandoned
Pray for the strength to trust God even when you are in the deepest despair
Ask God to help you remember that salvation belongs to Him alone (v.10)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Jonah 3 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jonah 4:1-11 aloud, focusing on the emotional shift from Jonah's anger to God's compassion.
tips: Note the repetition of 'I am angry' in Jonah's prayer (v.1, 4)
Listen for the contrast between Jonah's words ('I am angry') and God's response (v.2, 4)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is angry, WHAT they are doing, WHERE it happens, and WHY Jonah feels this way.
tips: Jonah's anger over God's mercy to Nineveh
The plant growing over Jonah's head (v.5-6)
The worm destroying the plant (v.6-7)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jonah's prayer (v.1-2), the plant's growth (v.5), or the worm's destruction (v.6-7)?
tips: Jonah's plea for death (v.2): 'It is better for me to die than to live'
The contrast between Jonah's care for the plant (v.5) and God's care for Nineveh (v.11)
The worm's destruction as a symbol of God's power over Jonah's emotions

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jonah trying to communicate to Israel about God's compassion and the cost of being angry?
tips: Jonah's anger shows that even the prophet who is supposed to represent God can be grieved by God's mercy
God's compassion for Nineveh (a city of sinners) is a call for Israel to extend mercy
The passage challenges Israel's narrow view of God's mercy

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The extent of Jonah's anger, the plant's significance, or God's response?
tips: Why does Jonah care about a plant that he didn't grow? (v.5-6) - It shows his emotional attachment to a temporary relief
The phrase 'I am angry' (v.1) is a human response to God's mercy, which is unusual for a prophet
The number 120,000 (v.11) is a large city with many people who are helpless, showing God's compassion for the lost

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Jonah's lesson about God's compassion to a situation where you feel angry at God's mercy?
tips: Identify one person in your life who needs God's mercy but you are angry about
Pray for the ability to see God's compassion in others, just as God saw in Nineveh
Write down how you can be a 'plant' of mercy for someone else this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about God's compassion for the lost and your own anger at God's mercy.
tips: Thank God for His compassion toward sinners
Ask God to help you not be angry when He shows mercy to others
Pray for the city of Nineveh (or a specific person) to be saved by God's mercy
